H0.text: Slowly is the manner in which thick lava flows.

H1.text: Quickly is the speed at which thick lava flows.

H2.text: Rapidly is how lava flows when it is thick.

H3.text: Steadily is how thick lava flows, as opposed to flowing quickly or slowly.

A4.text: The average speed of a lava flow scales as the square of its thickness divided by its viscosity.

A5.text: Lava flow speeds vary based primarily on viscosity and slope.

A6.text: An exceptional speed of 32 to 97 km/h (20 to 60 mph) was recorded following the collapse of a lava lake at Mount Nyiragongo.

A7.text: Viscosity depends continuously on temperature and pressure, it cannot be fully characterized by a finite number of experimental measurements.

A8.text: Viscosity is the internal resistance to flow, reflecting the internal stickiness of the fluid.

A9.text: Higher-temperature melts are less viscous, since more thermal energy is available to break bonds between oxygen and network formers.

A10.text: Felsic lavas usually erupt explosively to produce pyroclastic deposits.

A11.text: Its high silica content makes rhyolitic magma extremely viscous.

A12.text: Peralkaline rhyolites can be 10â€“30 times more fluid than typical calc-alkaline rhyolites.
